issue.title: It's unclear whether numeric_limits can be specialized by users

discussion.p:
/p2 notes that "unless explicitly prohibited", a user may conditionally specialize any class template for program-defined types. /p1 doesn't explicitly prohibit this, but it does create a bit of a grey area with its wording because it describes numeric_limits as a class template describing "the implementation's representation" of "the arithmetic types".
Since this type is about what the implementation provides, and about arithmetic types only, it's not clear whether a user can specialize it for their own library type such as ns::int256. ns::int256 isn't an arithmetic type (despite resembling one), so one can interpret /p2's (b) condition to mean that numeric_limits<ns::int256> needs to be explicitly specialized as if it were the primary template.

blockquote.p: [Drafting Note: Two mutually exclusive options are prepared, depicted below by Option A and Option B, respectively.]

resolution.p: Option A: (This assumes that the above described scenario is intended to be supported)

li.p: Add the following new paragraph at the end of as indicated:

blockquote.p: [Drafting Note: The particular wording form "emulating an arithmetic type" has been borrowed from Table 99 — Cpp17Clock requirements [tab:time.clock] and p2, respectively.]

p.ins: -?- The numeric_limits template may be specialized for program-defined types that are emulating an arithmetic type.

resolution.p: Option B: (This assumes that the above described scenario is not intended to be supported)

li.p: Add the following new paragraph at the end of as indicated:

blockquote.p: [Drafting Note: The particular wording form has been borrowed from p2 and p1, respectively.]

p.ins: -?- If a program declares an explicit or partial specialization of numeric_limits, the program is ill-formed, no diagnostic required.
